title: Babcock enjoys £100m boost as it takes on Navy helicopter work

Mon, Oct 12, 2015, 14:28 BST - UK Markets close in 2 hrs 2 mins Babcock enjoys £100m boost as it takes on Navy helicopter work By Alan Tovey | Telegraph – 51 minutes ago 0.036 0.000 
Engineering support giant takes on repairs of Royal Navy helicopters and extends deal to maintain Army equipment 
Babcock International ’s revenues will be boosted by £100m a year after the engineering support group landed a contract to service Royal Navy helicopters and expanded its deal to maintain weapons and vehicles for the Ministry of Defence. 
The FTSE 100 business has been awarded a five-year agreement to maintain the Navy’s Merlin, Sea King, Lynx and Wildcat helicopters and provide airfield engineering services and support at bases in the South West of England. 
The contract will be up and running by the start of 2016 and will involve the transfer of a large number of staff to Babcock. 
Last year Babcock completed a £1.6bn deal to buy helicopter group Avincis in its largest ever acquisition. The company launched a £1bn rights issue to help fund the purchase and some analysts questioned the price being paid. 
However Babcock said that the experience of servicing helicopters after taking over Avincis helped it to secure the Navy deal. 
Babcock also said that its contract to service and store the Army’s light weapons and vehicles had been enlarged after “successfully meeting an early milestone in the service provision”. As a result the company will take on further responsibilities. 
Peter Rogers, Babcock chief executive, said: “We are delighted to continue to grow our partnership with the MoD, both in the air and on the ground. Babcock is committed to delivering the improved performance levels, enhanced operational capability and increased cost effectiveness which are critical for our customers.” 
In December last year the company struck a 10-year contract with the MoD to take over maintaining British Army equipment. The blue-chip company paid £140m for the Defence Support Group’s land business, a Government Trading Fund owned by MoD that maintained the Armed Forces’ equipment. 
At the time Babcock estimated that providing maintenance, overhaul, repair and storage for vehicles such as Warrior armoured personnel carriers and Challenger (Hamburg: 4SE.HM - news ) tanks would generate revenues of about £2bn over the contact’s 10-year duration. There is also an option for the contract to be extended by five years. 
Last year the company had annual revenues of £4bn and made a pre-tax profit of £313m.
